support_summary: Expression of polyQ-expanded ATXN3 leads to an accumulation of DNA damage, indicated by a dramatic increase in the formation of TP53BP1 (53BP1) foci.

functions.cellular_process: The inhibition of the DNA repair enzyme PNKP by mutant ATXN3 results in an accumulation of DNA double-strand breaks. These breaks trigger the activation of ATM kinase, which then orchestrates the recruitment of downstream DNA damage response factors to the sites of damage.
functions.effect_description: As a direct consequence of ATM activation, the tumor suppressor p53-binding protein 1 (TP53BP1) is recruited to the DNA double-strand breaks, where it accumulates and forms distinct nuclear foci. These foci serve as a key cellular marker for DNA damage and an active DNA damage response pathway.
biological_consequence: Mutant ATXN3 inactivates PNKP -> DNA double-strand breaks accumulate -> ATM is activated -> TP53BP1 is recruited to the sites of DNA damage -> TP53BP1 forms nuclear foci, signaling an active DNA damage response.
specific_effects: SH-SY5Y cells expressing mutant ATXN3 (ATXN3-Q84) show approximately a 5-fold increase in the formation of 53BP1 nuclear foci compared to cells expressing wild-type ATXN3.

evidence.paper_title: Inactivation of PNKP by Mutant ATXN3 Triggers Apoptosis by Activating the DNA Damage-Response Pathway in SCA3
evidence.relevant_quote: To assess the accumulation of genomic DNA damage in cells expressing mutant ATXN3, we used anti-phospho-53BP1 (p-53BP1-S1778) antibody to perform immunohistochemical (IHC) analysis on the SH-SY5Y cells expressing wild-type vs. mutant ATXN3. We observed about a 5-fold increase in 53BP1 focus formation in the SH-SY5Y cells expressing ATXN3-Q84 over the cells expressing ATXN3-Q28...
